thread.title: MSU hockey flat in 4-2 home-opening loss to LSSU
thread.title_full: MSU hockey flat in 4-2 home-opening loss to LSSU

title: MSU hockey flat in 4-2 home-opening loss to LSSU
text:
MSU hockey flat in 4-2 home-opening loss to LSSU Chris Solari , Lansing State Journal 10:22 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Spartans' stopped penalty shot, Lakers' 3-goal second period the difference MSU freshman defenseman Zach Osburn moves the puck against Lake Superior State during the Spartans' home-opening game Thursday at Munn Arena in East Lansing. (Photo: Rey Del Rio/MSU Athletic Commuinications) 
EAST LANSING – It was meant to be a festive home opener in a season Michigan State hopes will turn its hockey program around. 
Instead, playing in front of mostly empty seats, the Spartans came out flat Thursday night. 
Lake Superior State scored three times in the second period, then added an empty-net goal with inside a minute to play to defeat MSU 4-2 in front of an announced crowd of 3,920 fans at Munn Arena. 
“You can’t blame anything on the crowd. It was really our performance that handicapped us,” MSU junior Joe Cox said. “It’s just something you can’t dwell on – they played a great game, and we have to come back (Friday) with a new mindset. It’s really in our hands. We didn’t play a good game today, and it obviously showed out there.” 
The Spartans defeated the Lakers in their first meeting, 4-1, on Oct. 10 in Portland, Maine. They’ll wrap up their weekend series at 7:05 p.m. Friday at Munn, part of a stretch in which MSU (1-3-1) will play 10 of its next 13 games at home. 
The turning point came with 12:06 left in the second period and the game tied 1-1. Cox got a short-handed breakaway and was slashed from behind on his drive to the net by the Lakers’ Eric Drapluk. MSU was awarded a penalty shot, but LSSU goalie Gordon Defiel smothered Cox’s shot after two fakes. 
“The goalie made a pretty nice stop. I threw pretty much everything I had at him,” Cox said. “If I’d have put that in, it’s 2-1. It might have changed things up.” 
The Lakers (2-3) got a short-handed goal a little more than two minutes later, with Bryce Schmitt punching in the puck past MSU goalie Jake Hildebrand on a two-on-one breakaway. C.J. Hayes scored a little less than three minutes later to make it 3-1 LSSU. 
MSU’s Mackenzie MacEachern scored his third goal of the season just 2:18 into the third period. 
Hildebrand was pulled with 2:04 remaining and the Spartans on a power play, but they couldn’t capitalize on the 6-on-4 advantage. LSSU’s Gage Torrel came out of the penalty box to score an empty-net goal with 56.6 seconds remaining. 
“Not good from start to finish,” MSU senior captain Michael Ferrantino said. “There wasn’t a whole lot of energy, there wasn’t a whole lot of puck possession, and there wasn’t too many good things. We shot ourselves in the foot a bit.” 
Hildebrand made 19 saves, and defenseman John Draeger added a goal for the Spartans. Friday's game 
MSU vs. Lake Superior State 
When: 7:05 p.m. 
Where: Munn Arena, East Lansing 
Radio: WJIM 1240-AM 17 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.lsj.com/1S02sAc TOP VIDEOS
